awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Narrow Graphene Nanoribbons with Tunable Electronic Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Solid-State and Materials Chemistry Program of the Division of Materials Research, Professor Alexander Sinitskii of University Nebraska at Lincoln is developing methods to synthesize large quantities of graphene nanoribbons. Graphene nanoribbons are single atom thick ribbons of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal pattern, and the ribbons, individually, are a fraction of the diameter of a human hair in width.  The electronic properties of graphene nanoribbons are very sensitive to their width and atomic composition along their edges, so it is important to design synthetic methods that can precisely control the atomic arrangement within the nanoribbons.  Professor Sinitskii is developing methods to prepare graphene nanoribbons from specifically designed molecular precursors.  The synthesis is performed in solution and can produce large quantities of graphene nanoribbons where their widths and atomic compositions of their edges can be specified.  Graphene nanoribbons display interesting electronic and magnetic properties, and therefore have potential applications in electronic technologies, such as field-effect transistors, logic gates, and photovoltaic devices.  To increase public awareness of the increasing role of carbon-based nanomaterials in everyday life and disseminate the results of this project, Professor Sinitskii is developing a series of educational video programs about recent discoveries in carbon-based nanoscience and nanotechnology. Professor Sinitskii is also developing new nanoscience courses to promote the education of graduate, undergraduate and high school students as well as high school teachers in the methods of materials chemistry and nanochemistry.

In this project, Professor Sinitskii is developing a bottom-up approach to the synthesis of atomically precise graphene nanoribbons based on the solution coupling of molecular precursors followed by oxidative cyclodehydrogenation.  A systematic study of graphene nanoribbons with different widths and geometries will provide a fundamental understanding of the interplay between the structural parameters of graphene nanoribbons and their band structures. Professor Sinitskii is also studying how the band structures of graphene nanoribbons can be further tuned by nitrogen doping along the edges of the ribbon.  The nanoribbons are being tested for applications in electronic devices, including field-effect transistors and gas sensors. The broader impacts of this project derive from the potential applications of graphene nanoribbons in carbon-based electronics and photovoltaics, and the planned educational and outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
Atomically precise graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) are at the forefront of nanocarbon research and hold great promise for electronic and optoelectronic applications. Theoretical and experimental studies showed that by changing the width and edge structure of GNRs it is possible to modulate their energy bandgap, engineer unusual magnetic properties and produce topological electronic states. Because of the high diversity and tunability of their properties, GNRs are widely regarded as promising materials for nanoelectronic devices and emerging quantum technologies. This project made several advances in the GNR field. Several GNRs with new structures were synthesized and characterized by microscopic and spectroscopic techniques. Some of these GNRs showed higher electrical conductivities than their previously reported analogs, which makes them promising for device applications. We also investigated the effect of heteroatom doping on electronic properties of GNRs by preparing a series of nitrogen-doped nanoribbons. We compared the N-doped GNRs with their undoped analogs and demonstrated the effect of dopants on the electronic properties of GNRs and their self-assembly behavior. We also developed several approaches for processing GNRs into ordered macroscopic structures, such as fibrils and thin films, that are compatible with the standard device fabrication procedures. Our device studies expanded the potential applications of GNRs from nanoelectronics and photovoltaics to highly efficient gas sensing. One of the new GNRs developed in this project exhibited significantly improved responsivities to low molecular weight alcohols compared to the benchmark graphitic materials, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes and reduced graphene oxide. Another GNR prepared in this study was employed in a very selective electronic nose system that could reliably recognize volatile organic compounds from different chemical classes, such as alcohols and amines. Overall, the studies performed in the framework of this project collectively demonstrate a complete methodology for a design of new atomically precise GNRs with improved properties, their synthesis, materials characterization, processing into bulk GNR assemblies suitable for device fabrication, and implementation in electronic devices. This methodology should be applicable to a broad range of future GNR studies. The results of this project were disclosed in 18 peer-reviewed publications and 1 patent.

This grant supported five graduate students, three of whom already defended their PhD dissertations, as well as three undergraduate students. Out of three graduated PhD students, one found employment in a government sector and the other two continued their academic careers as postdocs at a major research university and a US national laboratory. This project also resulted in a development of a nanotechnology laboratory course for undergraduate students, which was already taught six times in the Department of Chemistry of University of Nebraska - Lincoln and will be continuously offered after the end of this grant, and a series of educational videos on recent advances in nanoscience and nanotechnology. Some of the instructional materials that were developed in the framework of this project have been published in chemical education journals for broader dissemination.


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Alexander Sinitskii
